marketNews.title: MSCI Index Review Evaluation
marketNews.content: MSCI announced the evaluation for the Global Standard Index, Small Cap Index, and Micro Cap Index, effective from 3 March 2025 to 2 June 2025. The details are as follows: MSCI Indonesia Global Standard – No additions, exits: $INKP, $MDKA, $UNVR. MSCI Indonesia Small Cap – Additions: INKP, MDKA, $CLEO; Exits: $ERAA, $BJBR, $MTDL, $WIKA. MSCI Indonesia Micro Cap – No additions, no exits.

marketNews.title: Bank Indonesia Consumer Confidence Index Decline January 2025
marketNews.content: Bank Indonesia reported that the Indonesian consumer confidence index fell to 127.2 in January 2025, compared with 127.7 in December 2024, marking the first decline in three months. All sub‑indices of the current economic condition index decreased, while the consumer expectations index rose due to higher expectations for income and business activity.

marketNews.title: Bank Indonesia Retail Sales Forecast January 2025
marketNews.content: Bank Indonesia projected that retail sales in January 2025 will grow 0.4 percent year‑on‑year, despite a 4.8 percent month‑on‑month contraction, reflecting a normalization of demand after the holiday season. Retail sales in December 2024 grew 1.8 percent year‑on‑year and 5.9 percent month‑on‑month, with all commodity groups posting positive growth. The highest growth was recorded in information and communication equipment, spare parts and accessories, and cultural and recreational goods.

marketNews.title: OJK Targets Bank Credit Growth 2025
marketNews.content: The Financial Services Authority (OJK) set a target for bank credit growth of 9‑11 percent year‑on‑year in 2025, with a target for third‑party funds (DPK) growth of 6‑8 percent year‑on‑year. These targets remain unchanged from 2024 and are lower than Bank Indonesia's target of 11‑13 percent year‑on‑year for 2025. In 2024, the banking sector recorded credit growth of 10.39 percent year‑on‑year and DPK growth of 4.48 percent year‑on‑year.

marketNews.title: Bank Indonesia Liquidity Support for Housing Loans
marketNews.content: Bank Indonesia Governor Perry Warjiyo said on Tuesday (11 February) that the central bank will increase liquidity for banks that channel loans to the housing segment. The liquidity boost will be implemented by gradually lowering the minimum reserve requirement, freeing up 80 trillion rupiah of liquidity, up from the current 23.2 trillion rupiah. This measure aims to support the government's target of building three million houses per year.

marketNews.title: OJK Targets Increase of KBMI 4 Banks
marketNews.content: OJK Chief Executive Officer Dian Ediana Rae said on Tuesday (11 February) that the regulator aims to increase the number of banks classified in the Core Capital Adequacy Ratio (KBMI) 4 group to ten banks within the next two to three years, up from the current four. The expansion will be encouraged through voluntary consolidation. Strengthening the banking sector is considered essential to support the government's economic growth target of 8 percent. KBMI 4 banks are those with core capital exceeding 70 trillion rupiah; the current members are Bank Mandiri ($BMRI), Bank Central Asia ($BBCA), Bank Negara Indonesia ($BBNI), and Bank Rakyat Indonesia ($BBRI).

marketNews.title: Indonesia Stock Exchange Plans Short Selling Implementation
marketNews.content: BEI Development Director Jeffrey Hendrik said the exchange plans to implement short selling and intraday short selling between the end of the first quarter and the beginning of the second quarter of 2025. The move is intended to help investors cope with market uncertainty. BEI had previously issued two regulations for short selling on 3 October 2024, but no member has yet obtained a short‑selling license. The exchange is currently finalising the licensing process for members.

marketNews.title: ESDM Ministry Personnel Changes February 2025
marketNews.content: Deputy Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources Yuliot Tanjung announced that the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources deactivated the Director General of Oil and Gas, Achmad Muchtasyar, on Monday (10 February), less than a month after his appointment on 16 January 2025. The decision followed an internal evaluation. Minister Bahlil Lahadalia later stated that the Acting Director General position will be filled by the Director General of Mineral and Coal, Tri Winarno. The deactivation occurred after the Attorney General's Office raided the Ministry's Oil and Gas Directorate on Monday (10 February) in connection with alleged corruption related to crude oil and refinery product management at PT Pertamina during 2018‑2023.

tickerNews.title: BBRI FY24 Net Profit Slightly Below Expectations
tickerNews.content: Bank Rakyat Indonesia (BBRI) reported a decline in net profit for the fourth quarter of 2024 to 15.1 trillion rupiah, a decrease of 6.3 percent year‑on‑year and 1.8 percent quarter‑on‑quarter. The full‑year 2024 net profit amounted to 60.2 trillion rupiah, up 0.1 percent year‑on‑year, slightly below expectations at 98.5 percent of the consensus estimate. The performance was driven by: 1) Net Interest Margin (NIM) in line with guidance; 2) Cost of Credit (CoC) worse than guidance; and 3) credit growth below guidance. NIM fell to 7.4 percent in Q4 2024 (vs. 8.3 percent in Q4 2023 and 8.0 percent in Q3 2024), resulting in an average NIM of 7.74 percent for 2024 (vs. 8.2 percent in 2023), aligning with management guidance of 7.6‑8.0 percent. Loan yield rose to 13.2 percent in 2024 (vs. 13.1 percent in 2023), while cost of funds increased to 3.7 percent (vs. 3.1 percent in 2023). Management targets a slightly lower NIM of 7.3‑7.7 percent in 2025 and mentions a possible one‑off adjustment from modification loss that could affect NIM in the first half of 2025. CoC improved to 2.8 percent in Q4 2024 (vs. 2.2 percent in Q4 2023 and 3.2 percent in Q3 2024), but the annual CoC rose to 3.2 percent in 2024 (vs. 2.4 percent in 2023), above the management target of below 3 percent. The higher CoC was also driven by credit growth below guidance, leading to a 41 percent year‑on‑year increase in provision expenses and flat net profit. Management targets CoC of 3‑3.2 percent in 2025 and foresees a possible CoC increase in Q1 2025 due to front‑load provisioning by subsidiaries and modification loss, with normalization expected in the second half of 2025. Asset quality improved: Loan‑at‑Risk fell to 10.7 percent in Q4 2024 (vs. 12.5 percent in Q4 2023 and 11.7 percent in Q3 2024), and Gross NPL decreased to 2.8 percent (vs. 3.0 percent in Q4 2023 and 2.9 percent in Q3 2024), meeting the management goal of NPL below 3 percent. Special Mention Loans are expected to rise in the first half of 2025, while micro and ultra‑micro segment NPL remain high. Credit growth was 7 percent year‑on‑year in 2024 (vs. 11.2 percent in 2023 and 8.2 percent in Q3 2024), below the guidance range of 10‑12 percent. Growth was driven by corporate loans (+24 percent year‑on‑year) and consumer loans (+10 percent year‑on‑year), with slower growth in micro (+2.7 percent) and small (‑0.7 percent) segments. Deposits grew only 0.5 percent year‑on‑year as the bank reduced time deposits, resulting in a loan‑to‑deposit ratio of 88.9 percent in 2024 (vs. 84.2 percent in Q4 2023). Management targets credit growth of 7‑9 percent year‑on‑year in 2025. The dividend payout ratio for 2024 is planned at a minimum of 85 percent (vs. 80 percent in 2023), implying an approximate dividend yield of 8.3 percent based on the share price of 4,030 rupiah on 12 February 2025.

tickerNews.title: MSCI Seeks Investment Eligibility Input for BREN, CUAN, PTRO
tickerNews.content: MSCI announced that it will accept input from market participants and investors regarding the investment eligibility of Barito Renewable Energy (BREN), Petrindo Jaya Kreasi (CUAN), and Petrosea (PTRO) no later than 31 March 2025. MSCI also stated that it will provide clarification on the treatment of the three stocks for the May 2025 index review, with a final decision by 11 April 2025. Previously, MSCI announced that BREN, CUAN, and PTRO would not be included in the MSCI Indonesia Investable Market Index for the February 2025 review after analysis indicated potential investability concerns due to ownership concentration risks.

tickerNews.title: BMRI Involved in Danantara Investment Fund Financing
tickerNews.content: The Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources, Bahlil Lahadalia, said that downstream projects will be financed by the Danantara Investment Fund through Bank Mandiri. He also mentioned that the government targets investment funds for downstream projects across 28 commodities to reach 618 billion US dollars (approximately 10,124.7 trillion rupiah) by 2040. BMRI President Director Darmawan Junaidi said the bank is awaiting further information on the implementation and technical rules of the Danantara Investment Fund, which was established in early February 2025 following a revision of the State-Owned Enterprises Law.

tickerNews.title: TPIA Director Purchases 100,000 Shares
tickerNews.content: TPIA Director Chandra Asri Pacific, Raymond, bought 100,000 TPIA shares at an average price of 6,613 rupiah per share on 11 February 2025. The total transaction value was approximately 661.3 million rupiah. After the transaction, Raymond's ownership increased from 0.00219 percent to 0.00231 percent.

tickerNews.title: BBNI Director Comments on Hibank Shareholding
tickerNews.content: Bank Negara Indonesia (BBNI) President Director Royke Tumilaar said that Sea Group (NYSE: SE) cancelled its plan to become a shareholder of PT Bank Hibank Indonesia. He added that Hibank's development will proceed without external partners and that the shareholder composition remains unchanged. BBNI currently controls Hibank with a 63.92 percent stake after acquiring it in 2022.

tickerNews.title: BRMS Clarifies Mining Permit for PT Citra Palu Minerals
tickerNews.content: Bumi Resources Minerals (BRMS) clarified that its subsidiary PT Citra Palu Minerals has obtained government approval and environmental impact analysis (AMDAL) permits for both open‑pit and underground mining activities in Poboya, Palu, Central Sulawesi. The statement followed a request by a member of the DPR Commission XII, Mukhtaruddin, on Tuesday (11 February) for the government to investigate alleged environmental contamination from PT Citra Palu Minerals' gold mining operations. Earlier, mass protests had occurred due to concerns over potential environmental damage. BRMS reaffirmed that mining and ore‑processing activities at PT Citra Palu Minerals continue unabated.

tickerNews.title: DEWA Announces Private Placement Price Adjustment
tickerNews.content: Darma Henwa explained that the private placement price for DEWA was amended from 65 rupiah per share to 75 rupiah per share to achieve a better conversion price that reflects fair value, based on an independent appraisal by a public valuation firm (KJPP). The KJPP reassessed DEWA's financial projections, resulting in a revised fair value of 71.05 rupiah per share (up from 63.9 rupiah). DEWA stated that creditors have no objections to the price adjustment.

tickerNews.title: KLBF Announces 2025 Capex Allocation
tickerNews.content: Kalbe Farma (KLBF) Corporate External Communication, Hari Nugroho, said the company will allocate 1 trillion rupiah in capex for 2025, unchanged from 2024. The capex will support business expansion and routine expenditures such as machine maintenance. KLBF targets revenue and net profit growth of 8‑10 percent year‑on‑year in 2025, with margins expected to remain stable compared with 2024. To mitigate foreign‑exchange risk, KLBF will increase the use of Chinese yuan for raw material purchases from China.

tickerNews.title: AKRA Share Purchases by Controlling Shareholder and Commissioner
tickerNews.content: The controlling shareholder of AKR Corporindo, PT Arthakencana Rayatama, bought approximately 3.49 million AKRA shares at an average price of 1,115 rupiah per share between 6 and 10 February 2025, for a total transaction value of about 3.9 billion rupiah. After the transaction, PT Arthakencana Rayatama's ownership increased from roughly 63.69 percent to 63.71 percent. In a separate transaction, controlling shareholder and Principal Commissioner Soegiarto Adikoesoemo bought approximately 13.7 million AKRA shares at an average price of 1,108 rupiah per share between 7 and 11 February 2025, for a total of about 15.1 billion rupiah. His ownership rose from about 0.51 percent to 0.57 percent.

tickerNews.title: TAPG Share Purchase by Shareholder Theodore Permadi Rachmat
tickerNews.content: Triputra Agro Persada (TAPG) shareholder Theodore Permadi Rachmat bought approximately 1.4 million TAPG shares. The transaction was recorded in KSEI data on 10 February 2025; the average transaction price was not disclosed. After the purchase, his ownership increased from 5.19 percent to 5.20 percent.

tickerNews.title: SRAJ Share Purchase by Commissioner Jonathan Tahir
tickerNews.content: Sejahtera Raya (SRAJ) controlling shareholder and Principal Commissioner Jonathan Tahir bought approximately 16.8 million SRAJ shares at an average price of 1,880 rupiah per share on 14 January 2025, for a total transaction value of about 31.6 billion rupiah. After the transaction, his ownership increased from 0.49 percent to 0.63 percent.
